feed.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors

entry.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The conversation around the selection of a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) editor underscores the significance of appointing individuals deeply committed to and knowledgeable about the Bitcoin community. Ideal candidates like Kanzure and RubenSomsen are praised for their balanced approach and historical involvement, emphasizing the role's essence as a community service rather than a position of control. The temperament of the BIP editor is crucial; they must be open to engaging with various viewpoints without censorship.
Concerns regarding Tonoski's candidacy highlight his limited interest in the technical history of Bitcoin and a tendency towards zealotry, questioning his suitability for a role that demands neutrality and facilitation of community consensus. In contrast, Seccour is recommended for his credibility within the cryptocurrency community, evidenced by organizing global Bitcoin meetups, suggesting his potential contribution to related projects.
Proposals to modify the BIP process suggest shifting editors' focus from assessing technical soundness to ensuring submissions' relevance and formal appropriateness, aiming to streamline the review process through community expertise. Challenges such as delays in assigning numbers to proposals and merging approved changes indicate the need for more BIP editors to mitigate bottlenecks.
Debates on the governance of the BIP repository include suggestions for archiving the current repository and concerns over the overlap between mailing list moderators and BIP editors. This discussion advocates for a separation of powers to ensure impartiality and prevent conflicts of interest.
The urgency of expanding the editorial team is underscored, with Jon Atack and Roasbeef proposed as candidates due to their developer experience. There's consideration for involving non-developers like Seccour and Greg Tonoski in the triage process, highlighting the need for a comprehensive review mechanism to assess technical merit before assigning BIP numbers. This reflects efforts to involve both developers and non-developers in improving the BIP handling process.
Overall, discussions within the Bitcoin development community stress the importance of balancing inclusivity with technical rigor in the BIP review and assignment workflow, aiming for efficiency while adhering to community standards. The role of a BIP editor is critical in advancing the Bitcoin protocol, demanding deep technological understanding and collaboration spirit. Recent exchanges have also spotlighted Luke Dashjr's role in advocating for new BIP editor appointments, emphasizing effective governance within the Bitcoin ecosystem and the necessity of streamlining the BIP process to maintain its integrity and efficiency as detailed in [BIP 2](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0002.mediawikiuser-content-BIP_Editor_Responsibilities__Workflow).
